verses.verse: So I returned <WH7725>, and considered <WH7200> all the oppressions <WH6217> that are done <WH6213> under the sun <WH8121>: and behold the tears <WH1832> of such as were oppressed <WH6231>, and they had no comforter <WH5162>; and on the side <WH3027> of their oppressors <WH6231> there was power <WH3581>; but they had no comforter <WH5162>.
Wherefore I praised <WH7623> the dead <WH4191> which are already <WH3528> dead <WH4191> more than the living <WH2416> which are yet <WH5728> alive <WH2416>.
Yea, better <WH2896> is he than both <WH8147> they, which hath not yet <WH5728> been, who hath not seen <WH7200> the evil <WH7451> work <WH4639> that is done <WH6213> under the sun <WH8121>.

¶ Again, I considered <WH7200> all travail <WH5999>, and every right <WH3788> work <WH4639>, that for this a man <WH376> is envied <WH7068> of his neighbour <WH7453>. This is also vanity <WH1892> and vexation <WH7469> of spirit <WH7307>.
The fool <WH3684> foldeth <WH2263> his hands <WH3027> together <WH2263>, and eateth <WH398> his own flesh <WH1320>.
Better <WH2896> is an handful <WH3709> with quietness <WH5183>, than both the hands <WH2651> full <WH4393> with travail <WH5999> and vexation <WH7469> of spirit <WH7307>.
¶ Then I returned <WH7725>, and I saw <WH7200> vanity <WH1892> under the sun <WH8121>.

There is <WH3426> one <WH259> alone, and there is not a second <WH8145>; yea, he hath neither child <WH1121> nor brother <WH251>: yet is there no end <WH7093> of all his labour <WH5999>; neither is his eye <WH5869> satisfied <WH7646> with riches <WH6239>; neither saith he, For whom do I labour <WH6001>, and bereave <WH2637> my soul <WH5315> of good <WH2896>? This is also vanity <WH1892>, yea, it is a sore <WH7451> travail <WH6045>.
¶ Two <WH8147> are better <WH2896> than one <WH259>; because they have <WH3426> a good <WH2896> reward <WH7939> for their labour <WH5999>.

For if they fall <WH5307>, the one <WH259> will lift up <WH6965> his fellow <WH2270>: but woe <WH337> to him that is alone <WH259> when he falleth <WH5307>; for he hath not another <WH8145> to help him up <WH6965>.
Again <WH1571>, if two <WH8147> lie together <WH7901>, then they have heat <WH2552>: but how can one <WH259> be warm <WH3179> alone?
And if one <WH259> prevail <WH8630> against him, two <WH8147> shall withstand <WH5975> him; and a threefold <WH8027> cord <WH2339> is not quickly <WH4120> broken <WH5423>.
¶ Better <WH2896> is a poor <WH4542> and a wise <WH2450> child <WH3206> than an old <WH2205> and foolish <WH3684> king <WH4428>, who will <WH3045> no more be admonished <WH2094>.
For out of prison <WH631> <WH1004> he cometh <WH3318> to reign <WH4427>; whereas also he that is born <WH3205> in his kingdom <WH4438> becometh poor <WH7326>.
I considered <WH7200> all the living <WH2416> which walk <WH1980> under the sun <WH8121>, with the second <WH8145> child <WH3206> that shall stand up <WH5975> in his stead.

There is no end <WH7093> of all the people <WH5971>, even of all that have been before <WH6440> them: they also that come after <WH314> shall not rejoice <WH8055> in him. Surely this also is vanity <WH1892> and vexation <WH7475> of spirit <WH7307>.
